awd_titl_txt: RTG: Dynamics, Probability, and Partial Differential Equations in Pure and Applied Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
This research training group focuses on the interface of dynamical systems, probability theory, and partial differential equations. The project provides training opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral participants and aims to further the creativity, leadership, and professional development of postdoctoral fellows and faculty. The project includes outreach to local K-12 schools; research experiences for undergraduates, both during the academic year and summer, including partnerships with faculty at institutions that serve many students from groups underrepresented in the mathematical sciences; summer schools for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows; and a communication seminar. The program especially emphasizes communication, both because of its importance in reaching the wider public, and for its vital role within mathematics itself. Because probability, dynamics, and partial differential equations straddle the divide that often exists between pure and applied mathematics, these subjects provide an excellent training ground for effective communication. 

Dynamical systems, probability theory, and partial differential equations have rich interconnections and span the entire spectrum of mathematical activities from theory to applications. However, such interconnections are rarely explored in undergraduate or graduate education. This project aims to highlight these connections, which have proven so fruitful at the research frontier, and thereby to broaden the perspective of the next generation of mathematicians. The research activities will introduce students to problems relevant to societal and environmental issues. The emphasis on communication will enhance the professional development of participants, whether they find themselves working in education, industry, or research. The summer schools and research experiences for undergraduates will attract eligible participants nationwide. The educational modules created as part of the outreach and modeling activities will be available online to schools, universities, and the general public. The outreach activities will invite high school students to join in the excitement of mathematical discovery, while giving graduate students an opportunity to act as mentors.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RES TRAINING GROUPS IN THE MATH SCIENCES

por.por_cntn:
Dynamics, probability, and partial differential equations (PDEs) are key branches of contemporary mathematics. Dynamics, once focused on the motion of celestial and terrestrial bodies, led to chaos theory in the 1970s. Probability, with roots in 17th-century puzzles about games of chance, now applies to fields ranging from finance to cancer biology. PDEs describe phenomena like fluid flow, heat transfer, and the transmission of electrical impulses in the nervous system.

Our Research Training Group (RTG) at Cornell focused on the interplay among these branches, combining applied and theoretical approaches. Our goals were:

  • To increase Cornell undergraduates' interest in STEM fields.
  • To train more U.S. citizens and permanent residents in graduate and postdoctoral programs, particularly women and underrepresented minorities.
  • To foster collaboration between pure and applied mathematics.
  • To improve the oral and written communication skills of trainees and faculty, helping them convey the importance of mathematics to both specialists and the public.

Key Activities:

  • Research in probability, dynamics, and PDEs.
  • Annual undergraduate mathematical modeling contests.
  • Summer research experiences for undergraduates.
  • Summer schools for graduate students and postdocs.
  • Outreach to local K-12 schools and a high school seminar.
  • A seminar on math communication.

Outcomes:

Research Training: We supported 32 trainees (27 graduate students = 11 women and 16 men, and 5 postdocs = 1 woman and 4 men). These researchers published 51 papers on diverse topics, such as the behavior of pedestrian crowds, random matrices, and cryptocurrency liquidity spirals. Of the 32 trainees, 12 have secured academic positions at institutions like MIT, Princeton, and Texas A&M, while 8 were hired in the private sector (including Proctor and Gamble, Uber, and Zoox) or government roles (Sandia National Lab, U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission). Two trainees are in high school education and freelance science writing. The remainder are completing their PhDs.

Cornell Mathematical Contest in Modeling: This annual contest challenged undergraduates to solve real-world problems. For example, in 2020, participants worked on a model to optimize mobile food pantry schedules in collaboration with the Food Bank of the Southern Tier. Faculty and trainee judges provided feedback, enhancing the learning experience for all teams.

Summer Research for Undergraduates: Our summer research program involved 48 students from 25 institutions, including the University of Maryland, Howard University, and Cal State Fullerton. We focused on promoting diversity, with 21 female students, 4 Hispanic students, and 2 African American students participating. Research topics included optimization, mechanics, deep learning, and data-driven dynamical systems. Students contributed to 18 projects leading to publications or conference presentations. This integration of research, diversity, and inclusion exemplifies our commitment to developing the next generation of mathematicians and scientists.

Summer School: The Cornell Probability Summer School (CPSS) was held in 2019, 2022, and 2024, featuring lectures by experts on topics like stochastic PDEs and random matrices. The school hosted 180 participants, including 30 women, 20 underrepresented minorities, and 150 U.S. citizens and permanent residents. Attendees engaged in collaborative discussions and presented their research, gaining insight into cutting-edge developments in probability.

High School Seminar: In collaboration with Ithaca High School, we offered a not-for-credit seminar for 15 advanced high school students each fall. Cornell graduate students, supervised by faculty, taught topics beyond typical high school math, such as combinatorics and queueing chains. In the spring, the students worked in groups to present projects at Cornell. These seminars introduced students to advanced mathematics and fostered critical thinking and problem-solving skills.

Math Communication Seminar: Launched to improve communication skills, this seminar featured interactive exercises aimed at helping mathematicians engage better with both specialists and the public. A highlight was a workshop with the Alan Alda Center for Communicating Science in March 2021, where participants learned to improve empathy and audience engagement. Feedback was overwhelmingly positive, with participants reporting improved communication skills, increased confidence in presenting research, and an appreciation for empathy in public speaking.
